diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute and chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. The disease can also affect other body systems, such as the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs, but can also affect lymph nodes, kidneys, bones, and other body parts.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks cells that help the body fight infection, making a person more vulnerable to other infections and diseases. It is spread by contact with certain bodily fluids of a person with HIV, most commonly during unprotected sex or through sharing injection drug equipment.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato. Transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged or deer ticks, it can cause symptoms ranging from rash, fever, chills, and body aches to more severe symptoms like arthritis and neurological and cardiac disorders.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine and large joints. The condition is more common in men and often begins in early adulthood.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation of the joints, eyes, or urethra and sometimes sores on the skin and mucus membranes. It's triggered by an infection in another part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body. People with fibromyalgia may also have other symptoms, such as tiredness, sleep problems, memory issues, and greater sensitivity to pain.

diagnoses: Eosinophilic disorders (e.g., eosinophilic esophagitis, hypereosinophilic syndrome)
Thyroid Disorders (hyperthyroidism/hypothyroidism affecting attention and anxiety levels)
Secondary Thrombocytosis due to Inflammation or Infection

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include erythema migrans, headache, fever, and fatigue. If left untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system, potentially causing cognitive dysfunction and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily causes dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also lead to cognitive dysfunction, lymphadenopathy and systemic manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy which could explain migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Patients can experience a wide range of symptoms, including oral ulcers (pain), genital ulcers, eye inflammation (leading to vision problems), skin rashes and lesions, and possibly affecting the brain (leading to symptoms of cognitive dysfunction).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect nearly any part of the body, notably the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including cognitive impairment, skin rashes often exacerbated by sunlight, joint pain, and potentially leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause symptoms such as cognitive dysfunction, vision problems, and pain in various parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight infection. Without treatment, it can lead to AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, cognitive dysfunction, and various dermatological conditions that may cause pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can present in various stages; secondary syphilis may cause skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions potentially leading to oral pain, while tertiary syphilis can affect the brain (neurosyphilis), causing cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. It commonly affects the lungs, but can also involve the lymph nodes, eyes, and skin, potentially causing a range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy, vision problems, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B or C
diagnoses.description: Viral infections that affect the liver and can lead to swelling, yellowing of the skin (jaundice), pain, and potentially cognitive issues due to the impact on the body’s systems, including potential lymphadenopathy as part of an immune response.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar, which over time can lead to problems with the nervous system (contributing to cognitive dysfunction and possibly affecting vision), and susceptibility to infections which might explain symptoms like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause complications such as angioedema and potentially influence conditions like fibrosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and tissue damage in virtually any part of the body, including the skin (leading to fibrosis), joints, and internal organs. It might also involve lymph node inflammation (lymphadenitis) and is known for causing cardiovascular symptoms like palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts from cells that become certain white blood cells (lymphocytes) in the bone marrow. The cancerous cells can spread to other parts of the body. Symptoms can include lymphadenitis, and due to the increased blood cell production, complications like polycythemia can occur.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart is unable to pump sufficiently to maintain blood flow to meet the body's needs. Heart failure can cause palpitations, and in severe cases, can lead to secondary polycythemia due to low oxygen levels.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, clumps of inflammatory cells, in various organs, causing fibrosis. It can affect the skin, causing angioedema, the lymph nodes leading to lymphadenitis, and the heart, potentially causing palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body. It is associated with angioedema and can cause symptoms related to a release of histamine, like palpitations and, indirectly, lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphadenitis, and symptoms may include fever, night sweats, and weight loss, alongside a potential for palpitations due to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Any of a large group of cancers of lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can cause lymphadenitis and may include varied symptoms depending on the specific type and location of the lymphoma.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of blood disorders characterized by an excessively high number of eosinophils over a long period. The syndrome can cause damage to the heart, skin, central nervous system, and other organs, potentially leading to symptoms such as fibrosis and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It leads to the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells. Over time, these cells can spread to other parts of the body, causing symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and potentially affecting the spleen (splenomegaly) which can be indirectly related to symptoms like angioedema.

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with associated gastrointestinal symptoms
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A migraine can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. They're caused by a temporary decrease in blood supply to part of your brain, which may last as little as five minutes.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by four main species of bacteria. Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of an infected black-legged tick, commonly known as a deer tick. Symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Peripheral neuropathy, a result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet. It can also affect other areas of your body.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. With voluntary muscle action progressively affected, patients in the later stages of the disease may become totally paralyzed.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with ITP)
